children.value: Functions of Several Variables and Partial Derivatives

children.label: Functions of Several Variables and Partial Derivatives

children.value: While there are some subtleties involved in moving from univariate to multivariate calculus, much of the intuition carries over.

children.value: A partial derivative measures how the function changes when
one variable changes and all others are held constant
The rules of partial differentiation are the same as those for univariate calculus, except that
all other variables are treated as constants

Q=AK1−αLα.Q = AK^{1-\alpha}L^\alpha.Q=AK1−αLα.

children.value: The marginal product of labor (MPL) can be found by taking the partial derivative of output with respect to labor:

children.html: ∂Q∂L=αAK1−αLα−1=αA(KL)1−α\frac{\partial Q}{\partial L} = \alpha A K^{1 - \alpha} L^{\alpha - 1} = \alpha A \left( \frac{K}{L} \right)^{1 - \alpha}∂L∂Q​=αAK1−αLα−1=αA(LK​)1−α

children.value: In neo-classical economics theory, workers are paid a real wage equal to their marginal productivity of labor. So in the equation above we see that the real wage and MPL increase with larger capital stock relative to labor.

children.html: ∂Q∂K=(1−α)AK−αLα=(1−α)A(LK)α\frac{\partial Q}{\partial K} = (1 - \alpha) A K^{-\alpha} L^{\alpha} = (1 - \alpha) A \left( \frac{L}{K} \right)^{\alpha}∂K∂Q​=(1−α)AK−αLα=(1−α)A(KL​)α

children.value: Which suggests that the rate of return to capital is relatively high in countries that have a relatively large labor-capital ratios. These high rates of returns should cause capital inflow from rich to poor countries. But why do we not see this in reality? See
In neoclassical theory, factors are paid their marginal products. Hence wages rise with capital intensity, and the return to capital is higher where labor is abundant.

children.html: ∂∂x[f(x,y)g(x,y)]=g(x,y)∂f(x,y)∂x+f(x,y)∂g(x,y)∂x,∂∂y[f(x,y)g(x,y)]=g(x,y)∂f(x,y)∂y+f(x,y)∂g(x,y)∂y.\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}[f(x,y)g(x,y)] &= g(x,y)\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x} + f(x,y)\frac{\partial g(x,y)}{\partial x}, \\[2em] \frac{\partial}{\partial y}[f(x,y)g(x,y)] &= g(x,y)\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y} + f(x,y)\frac{\partial g(x,y)}{\partial y}. \end{aligned}∂x∂​[f(x,y)g(x,y)]∂y∂​[f(x,y)g(x,y)]​=g(x,y)∂x∂f(x,y)​+f(x,y)∂x∂g(x,y)​,=g(x,y)∂y∂f(x,y)​+f(x,y)∂y∂g(x,y)​.​

∂∂x[f(x,y)g(x,y)]=g(x,y)∂f(x,y)∂x−f(x,y)∂g(x,y)∂x[g(x,y)]2,∂∂y[f(x,y)g(x,y)]=g(x,y)∂f(x,y)∂y−f(x,y)∂g(x,y)∂y[g(x,y)]2.\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{f(x,y)}{g(x,y)}\right] &= \frac{ g(x,y)\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x} - f(x,y)\frac{\partial g(x,y)}{\partial x} }{ [g(x,y)]^2 }, \\[2em] \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left[\frac{f(x,y)}{g(x,y)}\right] &= \frac{ g(x,y)\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y} - f(x,y)\frac{\partial g(x,y)}{\partial y} }{ [g(x,y)]^2 }. \end{aligned}∂x∂​[g(x,y)f(x,y)​]∂y∂​[g(x,y)f(x,y)​]​=[g(x,y)]2g(x,y)∂x∂f(x,y)​−f(x,y)∂x∂g(x,y)​​,=[g(x,y)]2g(x,y)∂y∂f(x,y)​−f(x,y)∂y∂g(x,y)​​.​

children.value: If all second-order partial derivatives are continuous, then

children.html: fij=fji.f_{ij} = f_{ji}.fij​=fji​.

children.value: Young’s Theorem ensures that the order of differentiation does not matter for well-behaved functions, a key assumption in optimization.
More generally, if all the partial derivatives of the function

children.html: f(x1,x2,…,xn)f(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n)f(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)

children.value: exist and are themselves differentiable with continuous derivatives, then

children.value:
Each of these second partial derivatives is negative, reflecting diminishing
marginal productivity.
The single cross partial derivative is

children.html: ∂2Q∂K∂L=∂2Q∂L∂K=(1−α)αAK−αLα−1,\frac{\partial^2 Q}{\partial K \partial L} = \frac{\partial^2 Q}{\partial L \partial K} = (1-\alpha)\alpha A K^{-\alpha}L^{\alpha-1},∂K∂L∂2Q​=∂L∂K∂2Q​=(1−α)αAK−αLα−1,
KKK
LLL

children.value: A positive cross partial derivative means that capital and labor are

: increasing the use of one input raises the marginal productivity of the other. At the same time, the negative second partial derivatives capture diminishing marginal productivity of each input on its own.

The second-order derivatives of the Cobb–Douglas production function can be
summarized by the Hessian matrix

children.html: H(Q)=[∂2Q∂K2∂2Q∂K∂L∂2Q∂L∂K∂2Q∂L2]H(Q) = \begin{bmatrix} \displaystyle \frac{\partial^2 Q}{\partial K^2} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial^2 Q}{\partial K \partial L} \\[1em] \displaystyle \frac{\partial^2 Q}{\partial L \partial K} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial^2 Q}{\partial L^2} \end{bmatrix}H(Q)=⎣⎡​∂K2∂2Q​∂L∂K∂2Q​​∂K∂L∂2Q​∂L2∂2Q​​⎦⎤​

children.value:
The signs of the Hessian entries reflect diminishing marginal productivity
(negative diagonal terms) and complementarity between inputs (positive
off-diagonal terms).
Composite Functions and Multivariate Chain Rules

children.label: Composite Functions and Multivariate Chain Rules

children.value: In the univariate case, we learnt that the derivative of the composite function

children.html: y=f(x)=g(h(x))y = f(x) = g(h(x))y=f(x)=g(h(x))
dydx=g′(h(x))h′(x).\frac{dy}{dx} = g'(h(x))h'(x).dxdy​=g′(h(x))h′(x).

children.value: A multivariate form of the chain rule can be used with multivariate compositefunctions.

children.value: The multivariate chain rule states that the total change in

children.html: yyy

children.value:
with respect to a
parameter is the sum of each marginal effect multiplied by how the corresponding
argument changes.

children.html: Total change=∑(marginal effect×change in argument).\text{Total change} = \sum \left( \text{marginal effect} \times \text{change in argument} \right).Total change=∑(marginal effect×change in argument).

children.value: We can take higher-order total differentials if required. Continuing with the same example, the second-order total differential is

children.html: d2z=12x2 dx2+16 dx dy+18y dy2.d^2 z = 12x^2\,dx^2 + 16\,dx\,dy + 18y\,dy^2.d2z=12x2dx2+16dxdy+18ydy2.

children.value: Connection to the Multivariate Chain Rule
The total differential provides a direct link to the multivariate chain rule.

children.value: A homothetic function is a monotonic transformation of a homogeneous function.

children.value: is a strictly monotonic transformation, i.e.,

g'(y) > 0 \quad \text{for all } y
\quad \text{or} \quad
g'(y) < 0 \quad \text{for all } y.

children.value: An interesting property of the Cobb–Douglas production function is that the ratio of its marginal products depends on the capital–labor ratio and not on the overall level of production.

children.value:
More generally, the slope of the level curves of any homogeneous function is constant along any ray from the origin.
The slope of a level curve of a function

children.value: Thus, as with homogeneous functions, the scaling factor

children.html: sss

children.value:
does not affect the slope of the level curve.
This shows that the slope of the level curves of
—a class that includes but is not limited to homogeneous functions—is not altered by proportional scaling of all its arguments.
constant slopes along rays from the origin
, a crucial property in production theory.

:::{comment}
## Chapter Summary

::::{admonition} Summary
:class: important

* Partial derivatives measure marginal effects holding other variables fixed
* Second and cross partials capture curvature and interaction effects
* The multivariate chain rule links composite functions
* Total differentials and derivatives measure combined effects
* Homogeneity and homotheticity explain scale and substitution properties
* These tools underpin multivariate and constrained optimization in economics
::::
:::

Lucas1990.label: Lucas1990
Lucas1990.html: Lucas, R. E. (1990). Why Doesn’t Capital Flow from Rich to Poor Countries? American Economic Review, 80(2), 92–96.
